Operation 'postBenefitsDocumentUpload' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, vague_description, missing_output_details, not_actionable. Original summary is passive and vague about the action. Description is completely missing. Added clarity about the initiation action, the 15-minute window, the GUID for tracking, and what the response contains. This helps AI agents understand this is a prerequisite step that must be followed by a PUT request.

data.current_summary: Get a location for subsequent document upload PUT request
data.summary_suggestion: Initiate benefits document submission and obtain upload location
data.description_suggestion: Initiates a new benefits document submission and returns a unique submission identifier (GUID) and a pre-signed upload location URL. The returned location URL is valid for 15 minutes and must be used with a PUT request to upload the actual document payload. This is the first step in the document submission workflow. Returns HTTP 202 Accepted with submission details including the GUID for tracking and the location URL for the subsequent PUT request.
data.reasoning: Original summary is passive and vague about the action. Description is completely missing. Added clarity about the initiation action, the 15-minute window, the GUID for tracking, and what the response contains. This helps AI agents understand this is a prerequisite step that must be followed by a PUT request.

message: Operation 'putBenefitsDocumentUpload' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Original summary is too passive and generic. Description has good technical details but lacks context about the workflow, authorization, and what happens after upload. Added clarity about the pre-signed URL requirement, the multipart format requirements, the ETag response, the lack of apikey requirement, and the next step for tracking. This helps AI agents understand the complete workflow and constraints.

data.current_description:
Accepts document metadata, document binary, and attachment binaries. Full URL, including
query parameters, provided from POST `/document_uploads`.

## Example Payload

The following demonstrates a (redacted) multipart payload suitable for submitting to the PUT
endpoint. Most programming languages should have provisions for assembling a multipart
payload like this without having to do so manually.

```
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="metadata"
Content-Type: application/json

{"veteranFirstName": "Jane",
"veteranLastName": "Doe",
"fileNumber": "012345678",
"zipCode": "97202",
"source": "MyVSO",
"docType": "21-22"
"businessLine": "CMP"}
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="content"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="attachment1"
Content-Type: application/pdf

<Binary PDF attachment contents>
--17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76--
```

This PUT request would have an overall HTTP Content-Type header:

```
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=17de1ed8f01442b2a2d7a93506314b76
```

Note that the Content-Disposition parameter "name" in each part must be the expected values
"metadata" , "content", "attachment1"..."attachmentN". The attachment attributes must be named 
exactly as they are listed here (case sensitive), for example: "attachment_1" or "Attachment2"
are invalid.

This is an example curl command:

```
curl -v -L -X PUT '<Location from \uploads>' -F 'metadata="{\"veteranFirstName\": \"Jane\",\"veteranLastName\": \"Doe\",\"fileNumber\": \"012345678\",\"zipCode\": \"97202\",\"source\": \"MyVSO\",\"docType\": \"21-22\",\"businessLine\": \"CMP\"}"';type=application/json' -F 'content=@"content.pdf"' -F 'attachment1=@"file1.pdf"' -F 'attachment2=@"another_file.pdf"'
```
data.summary_suggestion: Upload benefits document submission with metadata and attachments
data.description_suggestion: Uploads a complete benefits document submission to the pre-signed location URL obtained from the POST /uploads endpoint. The request must use multipart/form-data format and include: (1) metadata JSON containing Veteran information and claim details, (2) content PDF containing the primary benefits document, and (3) optional attachment PDFs (attachment1, attachment2, etc.). The submission is validated and queued for processing. Returns HTTP 200 with an ETag header containing an MD5 hash for data integrity verification. Note: No apikey header is required for this request as authorization is embedded in the signed URL. After successful upload, use GET /uploads/{id} to track submission status.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too passive and generic. Description has good technical details but lacks context about the workflow, authorization, and what happens after upload. Added clarity about the pre-signed URL requirement, the multipart format requirements, the ETag response, the lack of apikey requirement, and the next step for tracking. This helps AI agents understand the complete workflow and constraints.

message: Operation 'getBenefitsDocumentUploadStatus' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_context. Summary is adequate but description lacks important details about the possible status values, error information, and when to use this endpoint versus the bulk report endpoint. Added comprehensive status information, error handling details, and guidance on endpoint selection for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_summary: Get status for a previous benefits document upload
data.current_description:
A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the real-time status of a previously submitted benefits document submission using its submission identifier (GUID). Returns the current status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), the last update timestamp, and if applicable, error codes and details. For submissions in Error status, includes specific error codes and plain-language explanations. The updated_at field indicates when the status was last changed. This endpoint is not cached, providing the most current status information. Use this endpoint for individual submission tracking or use POST /uploads/report for bulk status checks of multiple submissions.
data.reasoning: Summary is adequate but description lacks important details about the possible status values, error information, and when to use this endpoint versus the bulk report endpoint. Added comprehensive status information, error handling details, and guidance on endpoint selection for AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'getBenefitsDocumentUploadStatusReport' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_context. data.current_summary: Get a bulk status report for a list of previous uploads
data.current_description:
Due to current system limitations, data for the `/uploads/report` endpoint is cached for one hour.

A request to the `/uploads/{id}` endpoint will return a real-time status for that GUID, and update its status in `/uploads/report`.

The `updated_at` field indicates the last time the status for a given GUID was updated.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the status of multiple previously submitted benefits document submissions in a single request. Accepts a list of submission identifiers (GUIDs) and returns status information for each submission including current status (Pending, Uploaded, Received, Processing, Success, VBMS, Error, or Expired), last update timestamp, and if applicable, error codes and details. Note: Data for this endpoint is cached for one hour, so status information may be up to one hour old. For real-time status of individual submissions, use GET /uploads/{id} instead. Returns an array of status objects, one for each requested GUID.
data.reasoning: Summary is adequate but description lacks clarity about the input format (list of GUIDs), output format (array of status objects), and the caching limitation's implications. Added details about input/output formats, status value options, error information, and explicit guidance on when to use this endpoint versus the single-submission endpoint for better AI agent decision-making.

Summary is good but description could be clearer about response codes and their meanings. Added explicit HTTP response codes with their meanings, clarified the Content-Type requirement, and emphasized that this is a pre-validation step before the full submission workflow. This helps AI agents understand the validation scope and how to handle different response codes.

data.current_summary: Validate an individual document against system file requirements
data.current_description:
Using this endpoint will decrease the likelihood of errors associated with individual documents during
the submission process. Validations performed:
 * Document is a valid PDF (Note: `Content-Type` header value must be "application/pdf")
* Document does not have a user password (an owner password is acceptable)
 * File size does not exceed 100 MB
* Page size does not exceed 78" x 101"

Each PDF document is sent as a direct file upload. The request body should contain nothing other than the document in
binary format. Binary multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata in JSON
 format.

This endpoint does NOT initiate the claims intake process or submit data to that process. After using this endpoint,
individual PDF documents can be combined and submitted as a payload using PUT `/path`.

A `200` response confirms that the individual document provided passes the system requirements.
 
A `422` response indicates one or more problems with the document that should be resolved before submitting it in the
full document submission payload.
data.description_suggestion: Validates an individual PDF document against VA Benefits Intake system requirements before submission. Performs the following validations: (1) Document is a valid PDF with Content-Type header set to "application/json", (2) Document does not have a user password (owner passwords are acceptable), (3) File size does not exceed 100 MB, (4) Page dimensions do not exceed 78" x 101". The request body must contain only the binary PDF document; multipart/form-data encoding is not supported. This endpoint does NOT validate metadata or initiate claims processing. Returns HTTP 200 if the document passes all validations, or HTTP 422 with error details if validation fails. Use this endpoint to pre-validate individual documents before combining them into a complete submission payload via PUT /uploads/{location}.
